revision.text:
{{Infobox building | name = 333 Bush Street | image = 333 Bush St., SF front from street level 2.JPG | image_size = 250 | location = 333 Bush Street
[[San Francisco]], [[California]] | coordinates = {{coord|37.7906|-122.4030|region:US-CA|display=inline,title}} | pushpin_map = United States San Francisco Central#California#USA | completion_date = 1986 | building_type = Commercial offices
Residential condominiums | roof = {{convert|151|m|abbr=on}} | floor_count = 43 | elevator_count = | cost = | floor_area = {{convert|50422|m2|abbr=on}} | architect = [[Skidmore, Owings & Merrill]] | structural_engineer= | main_contractor = | developer = | owner = [[Tishman Speyer]] | management = | references = {{ctbuh|3923}}{{emporis|118789}}{{Skyscraperpage|3454}}{{Structurae|s0021843}} }} '''333 Bush Street''' is a 43-[[Storey|floor]], {{convert|151|m|abbr=on}} mixed-use [[skyscraper]] located on Bush Street in the [[Financial District (San Francisco)|Financial District]] of [[San Francisco]], [[California]]. The building was completed in 1986 and was designed by [[Skidmore, Owings & Merrill]] and contains commercial offices as well as seven stories of individually owned residential [[condominium]]s. ==Recent ownership history== In 2009, the tower's owners, Hines and Sterling American Property, forfeited ownership to their lenders after the primary tenant, multinational law firm [[Heller Ehrman]] filed for bankruptcy and defaulted on rent payments leaving property 65 percent vacant.{{cite news |first=J.K. |last=Dineen |title=Brookfield Properties forecloses on 333 Bush in S.F. |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/stories/2009/12/14/story2.html |work=San Francisco Business Times | date=13 December 2009 | accessdate=12 February 2016}} In 2013, the building was purchased by a joint venture of Massachusetts Pension Reserves Investment Management Board and DivcoWest Properties for US$275 million.{{cite news |url=http://news.theregistrysf.com/mass-prim-buys-purchase-333-bush-street/ |title=Mass PRIM Buys Into Purchase of 333 Bush Street |first=Jon |last=Peterson |date=October 22, 2013 |work=The Registry}} In 2015, the property was acquired by [[Tishman Speyer]] for US$380 million.{{cite news |url=http://news.theregistrysf.com/tishman-speyer-to-buy-333-bush-in-san-francisco-near-700-per-square-foot-or-approx-380mm/ |title=Tishman Speyer to Buy 333 Bush in San Francisco Near $700 Per Square Foot or Approx. $380MM |first=Jon |last=Peterson |date=October 12, 2015 |work=The Registry}} ==Tenants== *[[State Compensation Insurance Fund]] *[[National Park Service Pacific West Regional Office]] ==See also== {{Portal|San Francisco Bay Area}} * [[List of tallest buildings in San Francisco|San Francisco's tallest buildings]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|333 Bush Street}} {{Buildings in San Francisco|state=collapsed}} [[Category:Skyscraper office buildings in San Francisco]] [[Category:Financial District, San Francisco]] [[Category:Residential skyscrapers in San Francisco]] [[Category:Brookfield Office Properties buildings]] [[Category:Office buildings completed in 1986]] [[Category:Residential buildings completed in 1986]] [[Category:1980s architecture in the United States]] [[Category:Skidmore, Owings & Merrill buildings]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox book | name = Administrative Behavior: a Study of Decision-Making Processes in Administrative Organization | image = Administrative Behavior 1st Edition 1947 Title Page.jpg | border = yes | caption = Title page of first edition | author = [[Herbert A. Simon]] | country = United States | language = English | publisher = [[Macmillan Publishers (United States)|Macmillan]] | pub_date = 1947 | media_type = Print ([[hardcover]]) | pages = xvi + 259 | oclc = 356505 | congress = HD31 .S55 }} '''''Administrative Behavior: a Study of Decision-Making Processes in Administrative Organization''''' is a book written by [[Herbert A. Simon]] (1916–2001). It asserts that "[[Decision making|decision-making]] is the heart of [[Administration of business|administration]], and that the vocabulary of administrative theory must be derived from the logic and psychology of human choice", and it attempts to describe administrative [[organization]]s "in a way that will provide the basis for scientific analysis".{{cite book | last = Simon | first = Herbert A. | title = Administrative Behavior: a Study of Decision-Making Processes in Administrative Organization | publisher = Macmillan | location = New York | year = 1947 | edition=1st | oclc = 356505}}{{rp|xiii-xiv}}{{cite book | last = Simon | first = Herbert A. | title = Administrative Behavior: a Study of Decision-Making Processes in Administrative Organization | publisher = Macmillan | location = New York | year = 1957 | edition=2nd | oclc = 964597}}{{rp|xlv-xlvi}}{{cite book | last = Simon | first = Herbert A. | title = Administrative Behavior: a Study of Decision-Making Processes in Administrative Organization | publisher = Free Press | location = New York | year = 1976 | edition=3rd | isbn = 0029289718}}{{rp|xlvii-xlviii}}{{cite book | last = Simon | first = Herbert A. | title = Administrative Behavior: a Study of Decision-Making Processes in Administrative Organizations | publisher = Free Press | location = New York | year = 1997 | edition=4th | isbn = 0684835827 }}{{rp|xi}} The first edition was published in 1947; the second, in 1957; the third, in 1976; and the fourth, in 1997. As summarized in a 2001 obituary of Simon, the book "reject[ed] the notion of an omniscient 'economic man' capable of making decisions that bring the greatest benefit possible and substitut[ed] instead the idea of 'administrative man' who '[[Satisficing|satisfices]]—looks for a course of action that is satisfactory'".{{cite news|last=Lewis|first=Paul|title=Herbert A. Simon Dies at 84; Won a Nobel for Economics|work=New York Times|page=13|date=10 February 2001|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/02/10/business/herbert-a-simon-dies-at-84-won-a-nobel-for-economics.html}} ''Administrative Behavior'' laid the foundation for the economic movement known as the [[Carnegie School]]. The book crosses [[social science]] disciplines such as [[political science]] and [[economics]].{{cite journal|last1=Augier|first1=Mie|title=''Administrative Behavior: A Study of Decision-Making Processes in Administrative Organizations'' (book review)|journal=The Economic Journal|volume=112|issue=480|year=2002|pages=F386–F388|doi=10.1111/1468-0297.t01-17-00050}} Simon returned to some of the ideas in the book in his later works, such as ''The Sciences of the Artificial'' (1969).{{cite journal |last1= Golembiewski |first1= Robert T. |year=1988 |title= Nobel Laureate Simon 'Looks Back': a Low-Frequency Mode |journal= Public Administration Quarterly |volume= 12|issue=3 |pages=275–300 |jstor= 40861423 |url=http://octopus.library.cmu.edu/cgi-bin/tiff2pdf/simon/box00069/fld05320/bdl0001/doc0001/simon.pdf }} The [[Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]] cited the book as "epoch-making" in awarding the 1978 [[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences]] to Simon.{{cite web |url=https://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/economics/laureates/1978/presentation-speech.html |title=The Prize in Economics 1978: Award Ceremony Speech |author =Carlson, Sune |date=16 October 1978 |accessdate= 2 May 2012}}{{cite web |url=https://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/economics/laureates/1978/press.html |title=The Prize in Economics 1978 – Press Release |author =Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences |date=16 October 1978 |accessdate= 2 May 2012}} A 1990 article in ''[[Public Administration Review]]'' named it the "[[public administration]] book of the half century" (1940-1990).{{cite journal|last1=Sherwood|first1=Frank P.|title=The Half-Century's 'Great Books' in Public Administration|journal=Public Administration Review|volume=50|issue=2|year=1990|pages=249–264|doi=10.2307/976872|jstor=976872}} It was voted the fifth most influential [[management]] book of the 20th century in a poll of the Fellows of the [[Academy of Management]].{{cite journal |last1= Bedeian |first1= Arthur G. |last2= Wren |first2= Daniel A.|authorlink1= Arthur G. Bedeian|authorlink2=Daniel A. Wren|date= Winter 2001 |title= Most Influential Management Books of the 20th Century |journal= Organizational Dynamics |volume=29 |issue=3 |pages= 221–225 |doi= 10.1016/S0090-2616(01)00022-5 | url = http://www.bus.lsu.edu/bedeian/articles/MostInfluentialBooks-OD2001.pdf}} ==Background== The book is based on Simon's doctoral thesis in [[political science]] at the [[University of Chicago]], which he began planning in 1937.{{Cite book | last1 = Simon | first1 = Herbert A. | title = Models of My Life | year = 1991 | publisher = Basic Books | location = [New York] | isbn = 0465046401 }}{{rp|53}} At the time, the chair of the political science department was [[Charles Edward Merriam]].{{rp|55–63}} Beginning in 1936, Simon worked as a half-time research assistant and then as a full-time staff member at the [[International City/County Management Association|International City Managers Association]] (ICMA).{{rp|69–92}}{{cite book | last = Crowther-Heyck | first = Hunter | title = Herbert A. Simon: the Bounds of Reason in Modern America | publisher = Johns Hopkins University Press | location = Baltimore | year = 2005 | isbn = 0801880254 }}{{rp|76–77,84–87,96–97}} Among other activities at ICMA, he learned about administration and about scientific collaboration from director Clarence Ridley, and published his first book with Ridley in 1938.{{rp|64,72}}{{cite book | last1 = Ridley | first1 = Clarence E. | last2 = Simon |first2 = Herbert A. | title = Measuring Municipal Activities: a Survey of Suggested Criteria and Reporting Forms for Appraising Administration | publisher = International City Managers Association | location = Chicago | year = 1938 | oclc = 2049544}} Although Simon cites Ridley as a major influence on his thinking, Simon did not actually work on his thesis while at ICMA.{{rp|64–65,69–72,74}} Simon took a position at the [[Institute of Governmental Studies|Bureau of Public Administration]] at the [[University of California, Berkeley]] between 1939 and 1942.{{rp|78–85}} It was at Berkeley that he completed his [[University of Chicago]] Ph.D. thesis, which was approved by a committee consisting of [[Leonard D. White]], C. Herman Pritchett, Clarence Ridley, and Charner Marquis Perry.{{rp|84}} Simon received his doctorate in 1942.{{rp|84–85}} ==Influences== In writing his thesis and book, Simon was influenced by ''[[The Functions of the Executive]]'' (1938) by [[Chester I. Barnard]]. In his 1991 [[autobiography]], Simon wrote that he found Barnard's book "wholly superior to the other administrative literature of the day and fully compatible with my preference for looking at management in decision-making terms".{{rp|73}} The book, which Simon read "with painstaking care", motivated Simon to reflect upon his experiences and to focus on administrative decision making.{{rp|73–74,86–87}} In a 1988 interview, Simon was quoted as follows:
Of course I built squarely on Barnard, and have always felt deeply indebted to him; science is a cumulative endeavor...In the book itself there are fourteen references to Barnard...the notions of the contribution-inducement equilibrium, authority, and zone of acceptance were all derived from Barnard...What I would now regard as the principal novelties in ''Administative'' [sic] ''Behavior'' are the development of the concept of organizational identification...the description of the decision process in terms of the processing of decision premises, and the [[bounded rationality]] notions...Most of the rest is highly "Barnardian", and certainly even those "novel" ideas are in no way inconsistent with Barnard's view of organizations.
Mitchell and Scott have noted similarities in Barnard's and Simon's concepts of authority, organizational equilibrium, and decision making.{{cite journal |last1= Mitchell |first1= Terence R. |last2= Scott |first2= William G. |date= Fall 1988|title= The Barnard-Simon Contribution: a Vanished Legacy|journal= Public Administration Quarterly|volume=12 |issue=3 |pages= 348–368|jstor=40861427}}{{rp|349–352}}{{Cite book | last1 = Mahoney | first1 = Joseph T. | title = Economic Foundations of Strategy | year = 2005 | publisher = SAGE | location = Thousand Oaks, CA | isbn = 1-4129-0543-5 | chapter = Chapter 1: Behavioral Theory of the Firm | pages = 1–53 | url = http://www.sagepub.com/upm-data/5029_Mahoney_Chapter_1.pdf }}{{rp|9}} For example, Barnard's "zone of indifference" (a subordinate's unquestioned acceptance of authority) became Simon's "zone of acceptance".{{rp|350}}{{cite journal |last1= Golembiewski |first1= Robert T. |year= 1988|title= Perspectives on Simon's Administrative Behavior: Stock-Taking on the Fortieth Anniversary – Part I |journal= Public Administration Quarterly |volume=12 |issue= 3|pages=259–382|jstor=40861422}}{{rp|266}} In addition, Mitchell and Scott concluded that both Simon and Barnard believed that large organizations control individuals' behavior and manipulate their opinions.{{rp|357–364}} Philosophers who influenced Simon include [[William James]], [[John Dewey]], [[A. J. Ayer]], and [[Rudolf Carnap]].{{rp|45–46,80,82,88,90,93,96,101,186,195,199}}{{rp|53–54,58–59}}{{rp|99–101}}{{cite journal|last1=Kerr|first1=Gerry|title=The Development History and Philosophical Sources of Herbert Simon's ''Administrative Behavior''|journal=Journal of Management History|volume=13|issue=3|year=2007|pages=255–268|doi=10.1108/17511340710754707}} The ideas of behavioral psychologist [[Edward C. Tolman]] and sociologist [[Talcott Parsons]] also contributed to Simon's work.{{rp|86,114,190–191}}{{rp|101–105}} Simon characterized his own philosophical approach as [[logical positivism]].{{rp|45}}{{rp|253}} ==Editions== ===Preliminary (1945)=== In 1945, when Simon was at the [[Illinois Institute of Technology]], he sent [[mimeograph]]ed copies of a preliminary version of the book (which was similar to his thesis) to about 200 people he thought might be interested in his work.{{rp|130–131}} One of the recipients of the preliminary version was Barnard. Although Simon did not know Barnard personally, Barnard sent a total of 25 pages of detailed comments to Simon, which resulted in a thorough revision of the book.{{rp|131–133}} Simon then asked Barnard to write the book's foreword.{{rp|88}} ===1st (1947)=== The first edition had 16 pages of [[Book design#Front matter|front matter]] (e.g., a Foreword by Chester Barnard, a Preface, and Acknowledgements), as well as 259 pages of [[Book design#Body matter|body matter]] (i.e., Chapters I-XI) and [[Book design#Back matter|back matter]] (Appendix and Index). The published first edition was different from the preliminary version in many ways, including:{{rp|86}}{{rp|133–134}} * Mathematical appendices and a comparison of rats and humans in organizations was removed * The chapters were rearranged, with "Some Problems of Administrative Theory" moved up to Chapter II * Some discussion of [[logical positivism]] was deleted * There was more discussion of communication within organizations * Material that could be considered "political" (e.g., passages that appeared to support [[New Deal]] economics) had been taken out In the Foreword, Barnard states that Simon's conclusions are "consonant with [his] experience" as an executive, and expresses hope that "ultimately it may be possible to state principles of general organization".{{rp|ix-xii}}{{rp|xli-xliv}}{{rp|xliiii-xlvi}} In the Acknowledgements, Simon thanked Barnard for ''The Functions of the Executive'', for "the extremely careful critical review he gave the preliminary version of this book", and for his Foreword.{{rp|xv-xvi}}{{rp|xlvii-xlviii }}{{rp|xlix-l}}{{rp|xiii}} ===2nd (1957)=== The second edition featured a new Introduction, causing the book to contain 48 pages of front matter and 259 pages of body and back matter. The Introduction summarized the book's structure, suggested how practitioners might apply the book's lessons, discussed the concepts of rational behavior and [[satisficing]], commented on specific chapters in the book, and provided recent references.{{rp|ix-xxxix}}{{cite journal|last1=Sent|first1=Esther-Mirjam|title= Administrative Man Versus/As Economic Man (book review)|journal=Journal of Economic Methodology|volume=6|issue=1|year=1999|pages=133–139|doi=10.1080/13501789900000008}} ===3rd (1976)=== The third edition, which had 50 pages of front matter and 364 pages of body and back matter, placed the original Chapters I-XI and Appendix into a Part I.{{rp|1–253}} Its "Part II" consisted of six new chapters (XII through XVII) based on articles that Simon had written:{{rp|ix-x,xiii-xiv,255–356}}{{rp|256}} * XII: "On the Concept of Organizational Goal" (pages 257-278), originally published in 1964{{cite journal|last1=Simon|first1=Herbert A.|title=On the Concept of Organizational Goal|journal=Administrative Science Quarterly|volume=9|issue=1|year=1964|pages=1–22|doi=10.2307/2391519|jstor=2391519}} * XIII: "The Future of Information-Processing Technology" (pages 279-287), originally published in 1968{{cite journal|last1=Simon|first1=Herbert A.|title=The Future of Information Processing Technology|journal=Management Science|volume=14|issue=9|year=1968|pages=619–624|jstor=2628288|doi=10.1287/mnsc.14.9.619}} * XIV: "Applying Information Technology to Organization Design" (pages 288-308), originally published in 1973{{cite journal|last1=Simon|first1=Herbert A.|title=Applying Information Technology to Organization Design|journal=Public Administration Review|volume=33|issue=3|year=1973|pages=268–278|doi=10.2307/974804|jstor=974804}} * XV: "Selective Perception: the Identifications of Executives (with DeWitt C. Dearborn)" (pages 309-314), originally published in 1958{{cite journal|last1=Dearborn|first1=DeWitt C.|last2=Simon|first2=Herbert A.|title=Selective Perception: A Note on the Departmental Identifications of Executives|journal=Sociometry|volume=21|issue=2|year=1958|pages=140–144|doi=10.2307/2785898}} * XVI: "The Birth of an Organization" (pages 315-324), originally published in 1953{{cite journal|last1=Simon|first1=Herbert A.|title=Birth of an Organization: The Economic Cooperation Administration|journal=Public Administration Review|volume=13|issue=4|year=1953|pages=227–236|doi=10.2307/973005|jstor=973005}} * XVII: "The Business School: a Problem in Organizational Design" (pages 335-356), originally published in 1967{{cite journal|last1=Simon|first1=Herbert A.|title=The Business School a Problem in Organizational Design|journal=Journal of Management Studies|volume=4|issue=1|year=1967|pages=1–16|doi=10.1111/j.1467-6486.1967.tb00569.x}} ===4th (1997)=== [[File:Administrative Behavior 4th Edition 1997 Cover.jpg|thumb|right|Cover of 4th edition (1997); note change of subtitle to "...Organizations"]] For the fourth edition, with 15 pages of front matter and 368 pages of body and back matter, the last word in the subtitle was changed from "Organization" to "Organizations". The fourth edition lacked Barnard's foreword which had been present in the first through third editions. Instead of the third edition's lengthy Introduction and Part II, in the fourth edition the Introduction was briefer and Simon's commentaries followed each chapter of the original text.{{rp|256}} ==Summaries of Chapters I-XI and Appendix == The text and pagination of the 253 pages of Chapters I-XI and of the Appendix ("What Is an Administrative Science?") were the same in the 1st, 2nd, and 3rd editions. Although the text of Chapters I-XI and the Appendix was the same in the 4th edition, the pagination was different. === Chapter I. Decision-Making and Administrative Organization=== This chapter was based on a 1944 article with the same name in ''Public Administration Review''.{{cite journal|last1=Simon|first1=Herbert A.|title=Decision-Making and Administrative Organization|journal=Public Administration Review|volume=4|issue=1|year=1944|pages=16–30|doi=10.2307/972435|url= http://shelf1.library.cmu.edu/cgi-bin/tiff2pdf/simon/box00063/fld04779/bdl0001/doc0001/simon.pdf |jstor=972435}} Simon distinguishes between "value judgments" (which "lead toward the selection of final goals") and "factual judgments" (which "involve the implementation of such goals"),{{rp|4–5}}{{rp|4}} a topic which he explores more fully in Chapter III. The relationship of the individual and the group in decision-making is explored; for example, influences upon individuals include authority, organizational loyalty, efficiency, advice and information, and training.{{rp|11–16}}{{rp|9–13}} === Chapter II. Some Problems of Administrative Theory === Based on a 1946 article in ''Public Administration Review'' entitled "The Proverbs of Administration",{{cite journal|last1=Simon|first1=Herbert A.|title=The Proverbs of Administration|journal=Public Administration Review|volume=6|issue=1|year=1946|pages=53–67|doi=10.2307/973030|url= http://shelf1.library.cmu.edu/cgi-bin/tiff2pdf/simon/box00063/fld04787/bdl0001/doc0001/simon.pdf|jstor=973030}} Chapter II is notable for the following passage near its beginning:{{rp|20–21}}{{rp|29}}{{cite journal|last1=Banfield|first1=Edward C.|title=The Decision-Making Schema|journal=Public Administration Review|volume=17|issue=4|year=1957|pages=278–285|doi=10.2307/973419|jstor=973419}}{{rp|279}}
It is a fatal defect of the current principles of administration that, like proverbs, they occur in pairs. For almost every principle one can find an equally plausible and acceptable contradictory principle. Although the two principles of the pair will lead to exactly opposite organizational recommendations, there is nothing in the theory to indicate which is the proper one to apply. To substantiate this criticism, it is necessary to examine briefly some of the leading principles. # Administrative efficiency is increased by a specialization of the task among the group # Administrative efficiency is increased by arranging the members of the group in a determinate hierarchy of authority # Administrative efficiency is increased by limiting the span of control at any point in the hierarchy to a small number # Administrative efficiency is increased by grouping the workers
These principles were found in the 1937 book ''Papers on the Science of Administration'' edited by [[Luther Gulick (social scientist)|Luther Gulick]] and [[Lyndall Urwick]].{{rp|97}}{{cite book |title=Papers on the Science of Administration |editor1-first= Luther |editor1-last= Gulick |editor2-first= L.|editor2-last= Urwick |year=1937 |publisher= Institute of Public Administration, Columbia University|location= New York |oclc=995995|url= https://archive.org/details/papersonscienceo00guli }} After pointing out the shortcomings in the four principles, such as ambiguities and lack of empirical evidence, Simon states that "over-all efficiency must be the guiding criterion" in administrative organizations and that scientific methods must be applied to determine how to improve that efficiency.{{rp|36,42–44}}{{rp|43,48–49}} === Chapter III. Fact and Value in Decision-Making=== Chapter III "clarifies foundational aspects of the logic of choice."{{cite journal|last1=Cohen|first1=Michael D.|title=''Administrative Behavior'': Laying the Foundations for Cyert and March|journal=Organization Science|volume=18|issue=3|year=2007|pages=503–506|doi=10.1287/orsc.1070.0275}}{{rp|504}} The first section of the chapter provides details for the explanation in Chapter I of "facts" versus "values". The chapter's second section on "Policy and Administration" discusses how the legislative and executive branches of government apply facts and values.{{rp|52–59}}{{rp|61–67}} === Chapter IV. Rationality in Administrative Behavior=== After considering how the ideas of [[Instrumental value|means]] and [[Intrinsic value (ethics)|ends]] relate to decision-making,{{rp|504}} Simon distinguishes among "objectively", "subjectively", "consciously", "deliberately", "organizationally", and "personally" rational decisions.{{rp|76–77}}{{rp|85}} === Chapter V. The Psychology of Administrative Decisions=== In the first part of this chapter, "The Limits of Rationality", Simon wrote:{{rp|81}}{{rp|93–94}}
Actual behavior falls short, in at least three ways, of objective rationality…: :(1) Rationality requires a complete knowledge and anticipation of the consequences that will follow on each choice. In fact, knowledge of consequences is always fragmentary. :(2) Since these consequences lie in the future, imagination must supply the lack of experienced feeling in attaching value to them. But values can be only imperfectly anticipated. :(3) Rationality requires a choice among all possible alternative behaviors. In actual behavior, only a very few of all these possible alternatives ever come to mind.
The remainder of the chapter concerns "Purposive Behavior in the Individual" and "The Integration of Behavior". === Chapter VI. The Equilibrium of the Organization=== As summarized by Simon in the 4th edition's "Commentary on Chapter VI", the central idea of this chapter is that "the survival and success of organizations depend on their providing sufficient incentives to their members to secure the contributions that are needed to carry out the organizations' tasks".{{rp|164}} === Chapter VII. The Role of Authority=== Chapters VII-X deal with four ways in which an organization can influence an individual's decisions. In Chapter VII, Simon discusses the nature of authority and how it is used in organizations: for enforcing responsibility, for obtaining decision-making expertise, and for coordinating activity. Four methods are described for avoiding conflicts in authority when a subordinate has multiple superiors. === Chapter VIII. Communication=== Simon defines communication as "any process whereby decisional premises are transmitted from one member of an organization to another".{{rp|154}}{{rp|208}} Communication can be formal or informal, may need to be archived to provide "memory" for an organization, and is sometimes accomplished through training. The 4th edition's "Commentary on Chapter VIII" discusses computerized communications which were unavailable in 1947.{{rp|223–249}} === Chapter IX. The Criterion of Efficiency=== This chapter expands upon a concept that had been mentioned briefly in preceding chapters.{{rp|14,122}}{{rp|12,149–150}} In a for-profit organization, the "criterion of efficiency" states than an individual will select an alternative that will maximize income and minimize cost so as to "yield the greatest net (money) return to the organization".{{rp|172–173}}{{rp|250–251}} More generally (i.e., to include nonprofit organizations) the criterion causes "''that choice of alternatives which produces the largest result for the given application of resources''."{{rp|179}}{{rp|256}} In the remainder of the chapter, Simon counters criticisms of the efficiency criterion and outlines methods by which efficiency can be attained (e.g., by "functionalization" and by the public budgeting process). === Chapter X. Loyalties and Organizational Identification=== Following a concept of [[Harold Lasswell]], Simon asserts that "''a person identifies himself with a group when, in making a decision, he evaluates the several alternatives of choice in terms of their consequences for the specified group.''"{{rp|205}}{{rp|284}} Such organizational identification can be associated with decisions that are not optimal in terms of an organization's efficiency or adequacy ("the degree to which its goals have been reached").{{rp|212}}{{rp|290}} === Chapter XI. The Anatomy of Organization=== Simon describes the organizational decision-making process and writes:{{rp|240–241}}{{rp|322}}{{rp|263}}
The need for an administrative theory resides in the fact that there ''are'' practical limits to human rationality, and that these limits are not static, but depend upon the organizational environment in which the individual's decision takes place. The task of administration is so to design this environment that the individual will approach as close as practicable to rationality (judged in terms of the organization's goals) in his decisions.
=== Appendix: What Is an Administrative Science?=== In the final part of the book common to all editions, Simon discusses the "theoretical" (descriptive) aspects and "practical" aspects (i.e., leading toward the improved attainment of objectives) of the science of administration. ==Criticism== * [[Robert A. Dahl]] wrote in 1947 that a science of organizations was impossible due to cultural differences among organizations.{{rp|263}} Similarly, a 1957 review of the second edition questioned whether scientific studies of important aspects of organizational decision-making "under controlled conditions" could ever be undertaken. Simon responded to the 1957 review that "as knowledge advances...administrative practice will come to rest largely on scientifically tested knowledge of fundamental underlying mechanisms".{{cite journal|last1=Simon|first1=Herbert A.|title='The Decision-Making Schema': a Reply|journal=Public Administration Review|volume=18|issue=1|year=1958|pages=60–63|doi=10.2307/973736|url=http://octopus.library.cmu.edu/cgi-bin/tiff2pdf/simon/box00064/fld04871/bdl0001/doc0001/simon.pdf|jstor=973736}} * The book played a central role in what is known as the "Simon-Waldo debate" published in the ''[[American Political Science Review]]'' in 1952.{{rp|134–135}}{{cite journal |last1= Harmon |first1= Michael M. |year=1989|title= The Simon/Waldo Debate: a Review and Update|journal= Public Administration Quarterly |volume= 12|issue=4 |pages=437–451 |jstor= 40861434}}{{cite journal|last1=Gow|first1=James Iain|title=Decision Man: Herbert Simon in Search of Rationality|journal=Canadian Public Administration |volume=46|issue=1|year=2003|pages=120–126|doi=10.1111/j.1754-7121.2003.tb01583.x}} Using "[[purple prose]]", Simon and [[Dwight Waldo]] exchanged articles in which Simon "accuse[d] Waldo of logical unrigor" while Waldo "charge[d] Simon with philosophical myopia" due to Simon's reliance on logical positivism in ''Administrative Behavior''.{{rp|445–446}} * In 1962 [[Herbert Storing]] edited a book entitled ''Essays on the Scientific Study of Politics''; one of the essays therein, by Storing himself, critiqued ''Administrative Behavior''.{{cite book |title= Essays on the Scientific Study of Politics | editor1-last = Storing | editor1-first = Herbert J. | editor1-link = Herbert Storing |year=1962 |publisher= Holt, Rinehart and Winston |location= New York | chapter = The Science of Administration: Herbert A. Simon |oclc= 497089}} In his autobiography, Simon wrote that the essays in Storing's book "were such egregious examples of the practice of reading texts unsympathetically and without a genuine attempt to understand them that [he] never felt an urge to respond to them".{{rp|63,270}} One analysis notes differences in Storing's and Simon's styles of thinking ("dichotomous" versus "synthetic"), levels of abstraction, and "assumed 'goodness' of organizations".{{cite journal|last1= Chisholm |first1= Rupert F. |title = The Storing Critique Revisited: Simon as Seen in the Science of Politics|journal= Public Administration Quarterly|volume=12|issue=4|year=1989|pages=411–436|jstor=40861433}} * Simon does not offer any convincing replacement for the principles of organization that he critiques.{{rp|267}} * Simon's introductions and commentaries in the second through fourth editions interpret material in the first edition in a way that stretches its meaning or contradicts it.{{rp|256–257}} For example, Simon saw "satisficing man" in the 1947 text but other authors saw "maximizing man".{{rp|267}} * The fact/value and policy/administration distinctions have been criticized as unnecessary.{{rp|290–293}}{{rp|256}} * The book minimizes the role of emotions and habit in organizations.{{rp|506}} * Simon did not analyze how immoral behavior, such as [[police corruption]], can occur within organizations. * A 1990 essay asserts that Chapter II ("Some Problems of Administrative Theory") did not criticize Gulick's work fairly in that Gulick already recognized most of the problems that Simon discussed.{{cite journal|last1=Hammond|first1=Thomas H.|title=In Defence of Luther Gulick's 'Notes on the Theory of Organization'|journal=Public Administration|volume=68|issue=2|year=1990|pages=143–173|doi=10.1111/j.1467-9299.1990.tb00752.x}} ==Legacy== Simon felt that the reviews of the first edition "were generally kind, but the reviewers were not exhilerated [sic]", and that the book "created no sensation" at first.{{rp|88}} Nevertheless, it became notable for the following innovations: * A scientific approach to administration.{{rp|356–357}} * A focus on organizational decision making as the basis for organizational action, as opposed to John Dewey who emphasized habit and action.{{rp|9}}{{rp|505}} * The initial description of what would later be called "[[bounded rationality]],"{{rp|86,87}}{{rp|353}}{{cite journal|last1=Moe|first1=Terry M.|title=The New Economics of Organization|journal=American Journal of Political Science|volume=28|issue=4|year=1984|pages=739–777|doi=10.2307/2110997|jstor=2110997}}{{rp|743–744}} a term that one paper concludes first appeared in Simon's 1957 book ''Models of Man'',{{cite journal|last1=Klaes|first1= Matthias | last2= Sent |first2= Esther-Mirjam |title =A Conceptual History of the Emergence of Bounded Rationality|journal=History of Political Economy|volume=37|issue=1|year=2005|pages=27–59|doi=10.1215/00182702-37-1-27}} In the 1st edition of ''Administrative Behavior'', Simon used the phrases “limits to rationality” or “limits of rationality.”{{rp|39–41,80,241}}{{rp|36,38,40}} * The initial description of what a 1956 paper by Simon called ''[[satisficing]]''.{{cite journal|last1=Simon|first1=H. A.|title=Rational Choice and the Structure of the Environment|journal=Psychological Review|volume=63|issue=2|year=1956|pages=129–138|doi=10.1037/h0042769|pmid=13310708|url= http://octopus.library.cmu.edu/cgi-bin/tiff2pdf/simon/box00063/fld04854/bdl0001/doc0001/simon.pdf |quote= …it appears probable that, however adaptive the behavior of organisms in learning and choice situations, this adaptiveness falls far short of the ideal 'maximizing' postulated in economic theory. Evidently, organisms adapt well enough to 'satisfice'; they do not, in general, 'optimize'.}}{{rp|129,136}}{{cite journal|last1=Brown|first1=Reva|title=Consideration of the Origin of Herbert Simon's Theory of 'Satisficing' (1933-1947)|journal=Management Decision|volume=42|issue=10|year=2004|pages=1240–1256|doi=10.1108/00251740410568944}} As stated in the Introductions to the 2nd and 3rd editions, and in the 4th edition's "Commentary on Chapter V":{{rp|xxiv}}{{rp|xxviii}}{{rp|118}}
''The central concern of administrative theory is with the boundary between the rational and the nonrational aspects of human social behavior''. Administrative theory is peculiarly the theory of intended and bounded rationality – of the behavior of human beings who ''satisfice'' because they have not the wits to ''maximize''.
:Later in the 2nd through 4th editions, "to satisfice" is defined as "to look[] for a course of action that is satisfactory or 'good enough.'"{{rp|xxv}}{{rp|xxix}}{{rp|119}} The word is not used in the 1st edition of ''Administrative Behavior'', but the index to the 3rd edition indicates that pertinent passages are found in the 1st edition on pages 38-41, 80-81, and 240-244.{{rp|363}} * The concept of organizational identification in Chapter X.{{rp|87}}{{cite journal|last1=Jones|first1=Candace|last2=Volpe|first2=Elizabeth Hamilton|title=Organizational Identification: Extending our Understanding of Social Identities through Social Networks|journal=Journal of Organizational Behavior|volume=32|issue=3|year=2011|pages=413–434|doi=10.1002/job.694|url=https://www2.bc.edu/~jonescq/Jones_Volpe_2010_Org%20Identification_Social%20Identities%20Social%20Networks_JOB.pdf|access-date=2012-05-19|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150429074653/https://www2.bc.edu/~jonescq/Jones_Volpe_2010_Org%20Identification_Social%20Identities%20Social%20Networks_JOB.pdf|archive-date=2015-04-29|dead-url=yes|df=}} Simon would return to the concepts from ''Administrative Behavior'' in later books that he co-authored, including ''Public Administration'' (with Donald W. Smithburg and Victor A. Thompson, 1950); ''Organizations'' (with [[James G. March]], 1958); and ''The Sciences of the Artificial'' (1969).{{rp|157,229}}{{rp|505}}{{cite book | last1 = Simon | first1 = Herbert A. | last2 = Smithburg | first2 = Donald W. | last3 = Thompson | first3 = Victor A. | title = Public Administration | publisher = Knopf | location = New York | year = 1950| oclc = 1630919 }}{{cite book | last1 = March | first1 = James G.| last2 = Simon | first2 = Herbert A. | title = Organizations | publisher = Wiley | location = New York | year = 1958 | isbn = 0471567930 }}{{cite book | last1 = Simon | first1 = Herbert A. | title = The Sciences of the Artificial| publisher = M.I.T. Press | location = Cambridge, MA| year = 1969| oclc = 4087}} Among books written by other authors, ''Administrative Behavior'' influenced: * ''The Forest Ranger, a Study in Administrative Behavior'' by Herbert Kaufman (1960).{{cite book | last = Kaufman | first = Herbert | title = The Forest Ranger, a Study in Administrative Behavior | publisher = Resources for the Future, Johns Hopkins Press | location = Baltimore | year = 1960 | isbn = 068518420X }}{{cite journal|last1=Tipple|first1=Terence J.|last2=Wellman|first2=J. Douglas|title=Herbert Kaufman's Forest Ranger Thirty Years Later: From Simplicity and Homogeneity to Complexity and Diversity|journal=Public Administration Review|volume=51|issue=5|year=1991|pages=421–428|doi=10.2307/976411}}{{rp|422}} * ''[[Behavioral theory of the firm|A Behavioral Theory of the Firm]]'' by [[Richard Cyert]] and James G. March (1963).{{cite book | last = Rainey | first = Hal G.| authorlink = Hal G. Rainey |title = Understanding and Managing Public Organizations | publisher = Jossey-Bass| location = San Francisco| year = 1991 | edition = 1st| isbn = 1555423442}}{{rp|279}} Together, Simon (1947), March and Simon (1958), and Cyert and March (1963) are considered the "foundational works" for the "[[Carnegie School]]" of organizational decision-making and economics based at [[Carnegie Mellon University]].{{cite journal|last1=Gavetti|first1=Giovanni|last2=Levinthal|first2=Daniel|last3=Ocasio|first3=William|title=Perspective -- Neo-Carnegie: The Carnegie School's Past, Present, and Reconstructing for the Future|journal=Organization Science|volume=18|issue=3|year=2007|pages=523–536|doi=10.1287/orsc.1070.0277}} * ''[[Essence of Decision|Essence of Decision: Explaining the Cuban Missile Crisis]]'' by [[Graham T. Allison]] (1971), specifically the "organizational process model" explanation for the crisis.{{rp|253}}{{cite book | last=Allison | first= Graham T. | authorlink = Graham T. Allison| title=Essence of Decision: Explaining the Cuban Missile Crisis| publisher=Little, Brown |location=Boston| year=1971 | isbn=0673394123}} In 1978, [[Sune Carlson]] said in a speech at the ceremony awarding Simon a Nobel Prize in Economics:
…the study of the structure and the decision-making of the firm became an important task in economic science. … In his epoch-making book ''Administrative Behavior'', which first appeared in 1947 and which has been translated into nearly a dozen languages, as well as in a number of subsequent works, Simon describes the company as an adaptive system of physical, personal and social components, which are held together by a network of intercommunications and by the willingness of its members to co-operate and to work towards common goals. …
Nevertheless, it was reported that economists [[Albert Ando]] and [[William Baumol]] had "made little reference to ''Administrative Behavior''" in arguing to the Nobel Prize Committee that Simon should win.{{rp|138}} Between 1955 and 1988, the book was translated into 12 languages: Chinese, Dutch, Finnish, French, German, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Polish, Portuguese, Spanish, and Swedish. A set of 12 papers about the book appeared in ''Public Administration Quarterly'' in 1988-1989 for the book's 40th anniversary.{{Cite journal|title= ''Public Administration Quarterly'' Vol. 12, No. 3, Fall 1988 (Table of Contents) |publisher=Southern Public Administration Education Foundation | jstor = i40038729 }}{{cite journal |last1= Golembiewski |first1= Robert T. |year= 1988|title= Perspectives on Simon's Administrative Behavior: Stock-Taking on the Fortieth Anniversary – A Symposium, Part II |journal= Public Administration Quarterly |volume=12 |issue= 4|pages=389–391|jstor=40861431}}{{Cite journal|jstor=i40038730|title= ''Public Administration Quarterly'' Vol. 12, No. 4, Winter, 1989 (Table of Contents) |publisher=Southern Public Administration Education Foundation }} In 1990, Sherwood reported in ''Public Administration Review'' that 19 of 20 members of an informal advisory panel voted ''Administrative Behavior'' one of the "five or six most influential" books in academic [[public administration]] published between 1940 and 1990, making it the "public administration book of the half century."{{rp|249}} It was the "overwhelming leader" among the books nominated, receiving "twice as many nominations as any other book."{{rp|251,254}} Despite over 150,000 copies of the book having been sold in English, in a small survey of recent graduates from a [[Master of Public Administration]] program, Sherwood found widespread belief in the administrative proverbs that Simon attempted to discredit in Chapter II.{{rp|252,254}} The fourth edition of the book was released in 1997; its Introduction noted the book's "fiftieth birthday."{{rp|vii}} The book was cited in obituaries of Simon in 2001.{{cite news |title=Obituary: Professor Herbert Simon |author =Velupillai, K. Vela | authorlink = Vela Velupillai|newspaper= [[The Independent]] |date= 13 February 2001}} By 2009, the book had received 7,746 citations on [[Google Scholar]].{{cite journal|last1=Kerr|first1=Gerry|title=What Simon Said: the Impact of the Major Management Works of Herbert Simon|journal=Journal of Management History|volume=17|issue=4|year=2011|pages=399–419|doi=10.1108/17511341111164418}} Of the articles that cited the book, the articles that were most-cited concerned [[organizational learning]], the [[economic sociology]], [[transaction cost]] economics, and organizational decision making. ''Administrative Behavior'' appeared in at least three lists of "best" or "most influential" management and business books between 2001 and 2011.{{cite book | last = Crainer | first = Stuart | author-link=Stuart Crainer| title = The Ultimate Business Library: the Greatest Books That Made Management | publisher = Capstone Pub | edition = 3rd| location = Oxford | year = 2003 | isbn = 1841120596 | chapter = Herbert Simon, ''Administrative Behavior'' (1947) | pages = 257–259 }}{{Cite book | title = The Best Business Books Ever: The Most Influential Management Books You'll Never Have Time to Read | year = 2011 | publisher = Basic Books | location = New York | isbn = 9780465022366 | edition = 2nd | pages = 3–4 | chapter = ''Administrative Behavior'' by Herbert Simon }} As of 2012, the fourth edition of the book is still in print.{{cite web |url=https://catalog.simonandschuster.com/TitleDetails/TitleDetails.aspx?cid=1319&isbn=9780684835822 |title= Administrative Behavior, 4th Edition |work= |publisher= Simon & Schuster Digital Catalog |accessdate=May 11, 2012}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==Further reading== * {{cite journal |last1= Peng |first1= Wen-Shien |year=1992 |title= A Critique on H. A. Simon's Administrative Behavior Theory |journal= Public Administration Quarterly |volume=16 |issue=2 |pages=254–264 |jstor=40862285 }} * {{cite journal|last1=Dennard|first1=Linda F.|title=Neo-Darwinism and Simon's Bureaucratic Antihero|journal=Administration & Society|volume=26|issue=4|year=1995|pages=464–487|doi=10.1177/009539979502600403}} * {{cite journal|last1=Balducci|first1=Massimo|title=L'influence de ''Administrative behavior'' de H. Simon sur l'étude des organisations et sur la théorie du ''Public choice''|journal=Revue française d'administration publique|volume=131|issue=3|year=2009|pages=541–554|doi=10.3917/rfap.131.0541|language=French}} ==External links== * {{cite web |url= http://jespersimonsen.dk/Downloads/Simon-introduction.pdf |title= Herbert A. Simon: Administrative Behavior. How Organizations Can Be Understood in Terms of Decision Processes |author = Simonsen, Jesper |date= Spring 1994|publisher= Roskilde University |accessdate=May 11, 2012}} * {{cite journal|last=Rainey|first=Hal G.|authorlink= Hal G. Rainey |title=A Reflection on Herbert Simon: A Satisficing Search for Significance|journal=Administration & Society|volume=33|issue=5|year=2001|pages=491–507|doi=10.1177/00953990122019857|url= http://www.sagepub.com/upm-data/2664_11AS01.pdf}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.digitalsolipsist.com/2008/10/17/abstract-administrative-behavior-herbert-simon/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130121202424/http://www.digitalsolipsist.com/2008/10/17/abstract-administrative-behavior-herbert-simon/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=January 21, 2013 |title=Abstract – Administrative Behavior by Herbert Simon |author=Ching, Brandon D. |date=October 17, 2008 |work=Digital Solipsist blog |accessdate=May 11, 2012 }} [[Category:1947 books]] [[Category:Business books]] [[Category:Organizational behavior]] [[Category:Public administration books]]

{{Infobox organization |name = Adult Film Association of America |image = Adult_Film_Association_of_America_logo.png |image_border = |size = 220px |caption = AFAA logo |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = AFAA |motto = |formation = {{start date and age|1969}}<ref name="rimmer" /> |extinction = {{end date|1992}}<ref name="afwg0593" /> |type = [[Trade association]]<ref name="auto">{{cite web|last1=Russell|first1=Carrie A.|title=Adult Film Association of America|url=https://mtsu.edu/first-amendment/article/1155/adult-film-association-of-america|website=mtsu.edu|accessdate=26 April 2018}}</ref> |status = Merged with [[Free Speech Legal Defense Fund]]<ref name="afwg0593" /> |purpose = Advocacy for the adult film industry, opposition to censorship, presentation of erotic movie awards |headquarters = |location = United States |region_served = |membership = 285 producers, distributors, theater owners, cable programmers, and videocassette manufacturers in the [[adult film]] business<ref name="rimmer" /> |language = |leader_title = |leader_name = |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = |remarks = }}
The '''Adult Film Association of America''' ('''AFAA''') was the first [[United States|American]] association of [[pornographic film]] producers. It fought against [[censorship]] laws, attempted to defend the industry against prosecution for [[obscenity]], and held an annual [[#Erotic_Film_Awards|adult film awards ceremony]]. Founded in 1969, it continued separate operation until 1992 when it merged with [[Free Speech Coalition#Legal advocacy|Free Speech Legal Defense Fund]].<ref name="afwg0593" /> The organization was also host to the '''Erotic Film Awards''' which were held from 1977 until 1986.
== History ==
=== Origin, 1970s and 1980s === It was founded in 1969 in [[Kansas City, Missouri|Kansas City]], with Sam Chernoff of Astro-Jemco Film Co. as the first [[president]]. Other notable presidents included [[film producer]] [[David F. Friedman]], elected the third president in 1971, and re-elected four times before becoming [[Chairman]] of the Board, and erotic actress and [[magazine]] publisher [[Gloria Leonard]], who became president in 1986.<ref name="afw0187">"10th Annual Erotic Awards," ''Adam Film World'', January 1987, p. 7</ref>
It held adult [[film awards]] ceremonies for 10 years during the [[Golden Age of Porn]]. The first awards ceremony was held July 14, 1977, at the [[Ebell of Los Angeles|Wilshire Ebell Theatre]] in [[Los Angeles]] while religious protesters picketed outside,<ref name="afw1277">Thomas H. Hilton, "The First Annual Erotica Awards", ''Adam Film World'', December 1977, pp. 18-21.</ref> as they would several years thereafter.<ref name="rimmer">[[Robert Rimmer]], ''The X-Rated Videotape Guide'', Prometheus Books, 1993. {{ISBN|0-87975-799-X}}</ref><ref name="afw0179">Frank Thistle, "The Second Annual Erotica Awards," ''Adam Film World'', January 1979, pp. 24-27, 72.</ref><ref name="hs1179">"Silver Spoonfuls: A Star Is Porn," ''High Society'' magazine, November 1979, pp. 8-9.</ref><ref name="afw0180">Jules Griffon, "The Third Annual Erotica Awards", ''Adam Film World'', Vol. 7, No. 8, January 1980, pp. 24–27.</ref><ref name="genesis0180">Ken Gaul, "California Split—Oscar Night in XXX-Film Land," ''Genesis'' magazine, January 1980, pp. 58-60.</ref><ref name="pornstars8011">Richard Milner, "Erotica '80 Awards", ''Porn Stars, the Stag Erotic Series'', November–December 1980, pp. 86-89.</ref><ref name="cheri0784">"Go for Bold: Stars and stares compete at the 8th Annual Erotica Awards," ''Cheri Magazine'', July 1984, pp. 14-17.</ref> "These feverish protesters are such a familiar part of the ritual, they really should be listed in the program," sex news magazine ''Cheri'' stated after the 1983 awards.<ref name="cheri1183">"Winners, Sinners & Skin", ''Cheri'' magazine, November 1983, pp. 32-37.</ref>
With the advent of pornography on video, in early 1986 the AFAA renamed itself '''Adult Film and Video Association of America (AFVAA)'''<ref name="cheri0187" /> and added a new award category, [[#Best Adult Video|best adult video]]. The 10th annual awards, held at the Sheraton Premiere Hotel in Los Angeles on June 29, 1986, were the last.
The association changed its name again in 1987 to the '''Adult Video Association (AVA)'''.<ref>Sam Williams, [http://www.xbiz.com/articles/18467 "Gloria Leonard" feature], XBIZ.com, Dec. 6, 2006; retrieved June 1, 2012</ref> No awards were given for 1987.<ref name="afwg1988dir">"Award Winners: Adult Film Association of America Erotica Award", ''Adam Film World Guide'', Vol. 3, No. 12, March 1988, p. 11</ref> Instead, in mid-1988 they were replaced by an annual Night of the Stars dinner-dance and legal fundraiser,<ref>Bob Johnson, [http://www.xbiz.com/news/news_piece.php?id=135778&mi=all&q=night+of+the+stars "Free Speech Coalition Reaches 20-Year Milestone Fighting the Good Fight,"] Xbiz.com, retrieved June 28, 2012</ref> the fifth of which it held in June 1992 with more than 500 people in attendance, the association's biggest show ever.<ref name="afwg0593" /> [[#Lifetime_Achievement_Awards|Lifetime Achievement Awards]] were presented at the Night of the Stars, however, film awards were discontinued.
=== 1990s === By February 1992, the tables were turned – association members "picketed the Public Forum on Pornography sponsored by religious groups who hope to institute [[Motion Picture Production Code|morality codes]] back into all movies made."<ref name="afwg0593">Jeremy Stone, "1992: The Year in Porn", ''Adam Film World Guide'', May 1993, pp. 6-7 & 76</ref>
In October 1992, Video Vixens [[Trading Cards]] for [[Collecting|collectors]] were released with part of the profits going to the AVA. That same month, the AVA and Free Speech Legal Defense Fund, which had been organized in 1991, unified to create a new [[umbrella organization]], the '''[[Free Speech Coalition]] (FSC)'''.<ref name="afwg0593" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discountadultshopping.com/glorialeonard/glorialeonardbiography.html |title=The Life Of Legendary Porn Actress Gloria Leonard|website=discountadultshopping.com|accessdate=24 June 2016}}</ref> Its role as the [[trade association]] of the [[sex industry|adult entertainment industry]]<ref name="auto"/> was taken over by the FSC, which acknowledges the AFAA as its first [[ancestor]].<ref>[http://www.freespeechcoalition.com/aboutus.htm History of the Free Speech Coalition], Archived at: {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060513064546/http://www.freespeechcoalition.com/aboutus.htm |date=May 13, 2006 }}</ref>
=== AFAA award history=== [[Pornographic film actor|Pornographic actress]] [[Marilyn Chambers]] presented the very first award for [[#Best Picture|best erotic motion picture]] to the L. Sultana production of ''[[The Opening of Misty Beethoven]]'', while runner-up was ''Count the Ways'', produced by Virginia Ann Perry.<ref name="afw1277" /> [[Jennifer Welles]] and [[Jamie Gillis]] were the first winners in the [[#Best Actress|best actress]] and [[#Best Actor|best actor]] categories. Pornographic actor [[John Holmes (actor)|John Holmes]] told the crowd at the first year's awards, "In the not-too-far distant future we will proudly say that we were pioneers."<ref name="afw1277" />
Retroactive awards of merit were also given to five movies considered best from 1955 to 1975: ''[[Tonight for Sure]]'', ''Not Tonight, Henry!'' ''[[Trader Hornee]]'' and ''Sometime Sweet Susan''. ''[[Deep Throat (film)|Deep Throat]]'' was also honored as one of the top-grossing of all movies, including mainstream films, of [[1972 in film|1972]]. Board chairman Friedman said the AFAA was "much too busy fighting legal battles" in the early days to hold awards ceremonies, so these [[#Special Awards|special awards]] were intended to make up for not having presented them in the past.<ref name="afw1277" />
For a time the most notable erotic film awards were those of the AFAA, considered to be "the closest thing the porn world's got to filmdom's [[Academy Award|Oscar]] derby."<ref name="cheri0784" /> Many stars would arrive in chauffeur-driven limousines while some would vie for attention by arriving in a four-horse [[carriage]], a Roman [[chariot]], a [[horse]] or even an [[elephant]].<ref name="afwg0582">"The 5th Annual Erotica Awards", ''Adam Film World Guide'', May 1982, pp. 24-26.</ref> The third annual awards "drew a festive crowd of some 600 porn-people plus several hundred hard-core fans to the [[Hollywood Palladium]]."<ref name="afw0180" /> Subsequent awards shows even attracted celebrities such as ''[[Godfather Trilogy|The Godfather]]'' director [[Francis Ford Coppola]],<ref name="cheri0784" /><ref name="afwg0884">Kent Smith, "The 8th Annual Erotica Awards", ''Adam Film World Guide'', Vol. 2, No. 2, August 1984, pp. 22–25.</ref> singer [[Stephen Bishop (musician)|Stephen Bishop]]<ref name="afwg0884" /> and [[gonzo journalism|gonzo journalist]] [[Hunter S. Thompson]]<ref name="cheri0187">[[Candida Royalle]], "Porn On Parade: The 1986 AFAA Awards", ''Cheri Magazine'', Vol. 11, No. 6, January 1987, pp.40–41.</ref> to be part of the audience and comedian [[Jackie Gayle]]<ref name="afwg0884" /> and singer [[Jaye P. Morgan]] of ''[[The Gong Show]]'' to be part of evening's entertainment.<ref name="afwg0582" /> The fifth and eighth awards ceremonies were videotaped and offered to cable and subscription television<ref name="rimmer" /><ref name="afwg0582" /> and for sale on [[VHS]] cassettes while the seventh was taped for an August 1983 broadcast on [[Playboy TV]]. Other awards during the [[Golden Age of Porn|porno chic]] era included ''[[Adam Film World]]'s'' X-Caliber awards, first given out in 1975 and based on votes of fans,<ref name="afw1277" /> ''[[Hustler]]'' magazine's Erotic Movie Awards, first presented in 1977 and the [[Critics' Adult Film Association#CAFA Awards|Critics Adult Film Awards]], bestowed by a [[New York City|New York]]-based group of [[East Coast of the United States|East Coast]] adult sex film critics from 1981 to 1987.
By the third awards ceremony in 1980, although the concept was seen as positive, adult entertainment magazine ''[[Genesis (magazine)|Genesis]]'' reported they were "beginning to generate as much controversy as the regular [[Academy Award]]s, or more."<ref name="genesis0180" /> While it seemed "politicking" gave the Best Film award to ''Legend of Lady Blue'' over heavy favorites ''Sex World'' and ''Take Off'', the "most glaring lack of any validity" was shown by giving the best actor award to [[Aldo Ray]]. "The Erotica Awards are supposed to be presented to sex-film performers who both 'act' well and 'perform' well. In ''Sweet Savage'', not only did Aldo Ray not 'act' particularly well—his part was simply gratuitous...he never even performed at all. The fact is he never even took his clothes off, nor did he show up to receive his award."<ref name="genesis0180" /> Aside from that, ''Sweet Savage'' was released "well into 1979" and the films nominated were supposed to have been released in 1978, leaving the impression the AFAA gave him the award to "capitalize on his name and to obtain more media coverage."<ref name="genesis0180" /> ''Adam Film World Guide'', however, reported the following year's awards, which were presented in July 1981, "covered films released from mid-1980 to the middle of '81",<ref name="afwg0582" /> which could have meant ''Sweet Savage'' was eligible for awards in 1979 if the same time frame was considered. Meanwhile, ''Adam Film World'' noted Ray's award "was not surprising considering that one of the announced functions of the aFAA and its annual awards is to upgrade the image of the adult film industry in the public eye."<ref name="afw0180" />
Originally the Erotica Awards were determined by vote of the "association's membership of more than 700 producers, distributors and theater operators."<ref name="afwg0582" /> However, in later years the AFAA ceremony was increasingly accused of bias, with a "belief among some that the West Coast producers were controlling what films received the awards" after ''Amanda By Night'' was passed over for best film at the 1981 awards.<ref name="rimmer" /> Starting with the awards presented in 1982, the AFAA decided to appoint an independent jury of three persons not associated with the adult film industry to make the final choices from the five finalists in each category.<ref name="rimmer" /> Jurors subsequently included an assortment of men and women such as a sexologist,<ref name="cheri0186">"Film Strips: 'X' Marks the Spot," ''Cheri Magazine'', January 1986, pp. 12-19.</ref> author [[Robert Rimmer]]<ref name="rimmer" /> and journalists such as [[Brendan Gill]] of ''[[The New Yorker]]''<ref name="cheri0784" /> and other publications including ''[[Variety (magazine)|Daily Variety]]'', ''[[Playboy]]'', ''[[USA Today]]'' and the ''[[Los Angeles Herald Examiner]]''.<ref name="afw0187" /><ref name="afaa7">AFAA, "Seventh Annual Erotica Awards," official program, June 23, 1983.</ref>
However, criticism continued, especially for the best erotic scene victory of ''Virginia'' in 1984, which led to the founding of the [[X-Rated Critics Organization]] and its [[XRCO Award|Heart-On Awards]].<ref name="rimmer" /> The role of adult film awards has been mostly supplanted by the [[AVN Awards]], which also launched in 1984.
=== Credo === The AFAA had a credo that "recognized the responsibilities of adult filmmakers to the general public":<ref name="holliday">[[Jim Holliday]], ''Only the Best'', Cal Vista, 1986.</ref> 1. That films of adult subject matter will be produced for and exhibited to adult audiences and that persons not of legal age will not be admitted. 2. That the definition of an "adult" is that designation set by the constituted authorities of the community but in no event any persons under the age of 18 years. 3. That we will produce and exhibit only films that are in conformity with the Free Speech Provisions of the Constitution of the United States of America. 4. That we will respect the privacy of the general public in our advertising and public displays. 5. That we in ''no manner'' will condone, produce or exhibit child pornography in any form.

== Lifetime Achievement Awards == After the [[#Erotic_Film_Awards|Erotic Film Awards]] were discontinued, the association resumed presenting Lifetime Achievement Awards at its annual "Night of the Stars" fundraising event, starting in mid-1988. When the association merged into the [[Free Speech Coalition]] in late 1992, the new coalition took over the tradition.

===Hal Freeman 'Freedom Isn't Free' Award=== * 1989: [[Al Goldstein]]<ref name="afwg2004dir" /> * 1990: [[Bob Guccione]]<ref name="afwg2004dir" /> * 1991: Barry Freilich<ref name="afwg2004dir" /> * 1992: [[Phil Harvey]]<ref name="afwg2004dir" />
==Notes== {{Refbegin}} {{note|suppactor|1}} ''Adam Film World'' recorded the winner of this category in 1979 as having been a tie between Roger Caine and John Seeman.<ref name="afw0180" /> ''Cinema-X'' magazine recorded Roger Caine as the sole winner.<ref name="cinemax0180" />
{{note|language|2}} This award was called "Best Foreign Language Film" at the 1977 and 1981 awards shows. It was not awarded after 1981.
{{note|foreign|3}} IMDb states this movie, while advertised as the first X-rated movie made in Russia, was actually made in the U.S.<ref>{{IMDb title|0249711|Librianna, Bitch of the Black Sea}}</ref>
{{note|year|4}} ''Adam Film World'' reported both ''Seven Into Snowy'' as winner of "Best Musical Score" and also ''Get Your Nose Out Of My Pantyhose'' won "Best Original Musical Score", a different award,<ref name="afw0179" /> in 1978. However, the AFAA's seventh and eighth annual programs, which list previous years' winners, make no mention of ''Get Your Nose Out of My Pantyhose'' or any separate "Original" score award. As well, IMDb states "Get Your Nose Out of My Pantyhose" is not a movie, but a song from a movie called ''Breaker Beauties'', so ''Adam Film World's'' report of an "Original" score award may be erroneous.
{{note|song|5}} The official 8th Annual AFAA Erotic Film Awards program lists both songs as having won the award,<ref name="afaa8p" /> however Jim Holliday's ''Only the Best'' book only mentions "With You" from ''Roommates'' as winning.<ref name="holliday" /> ''Cheri'' magazine's coverage of the awards doesn't mention the category at all.<ref name="cheri0784" />
{{note|year|6}} This award was called "Best Production Values" at the 1979 and 1980 awards shows.<ref name="pornstars8011" /><ref name="afaa7" /><ref name="afaa8p" />
{{note|year|7}} ''Adam Film World''<ref name="afw1277" />' and ''Cinema Blue''<ref name="cinemablue" /> coverage of the first Erotica Awards both listed ''Not Tonight, Henry!'' as having won "Best Adult Film 1961-65" and ''Tonight For Sure'' as having won "Best Adult Film 1955-60". However, ''Not Tonight, Henry!'' premiered Dec. 30, 1960<ref name="afi">{{cite web|url=http://www.afi.com/members/catalog/|title=AFI CATALOG|work=afi.com|accessdate=24 June 2016}}</ref> in Los Angeles, while ''Tonight For Sure'' premiered in L.A., Oct. 25, 1962,<ref name="afi" /> so it's likely an error by the AFAA resulted in each film being given the award for the other's time period. Nominee ''Sinderella and the Golden Bra'' was listed in the correct time period. [[Jim Holliday]]'s book, ''Only the Best'', lists the movies as having won in the correct time periods, however.<ref name="holliday" /> {{Refend}}
==References== * [https://www.imdb.com/Sections/Awards/Adult_Film_Association_of_America/ IMDb: Adult Film Association of America] Listing of film awards handed out by the association
<references/>
{{adult entertainment awards}}

{{infobox_person | name = Ailsa Mellon Bruce | image = Alisa Mellon, 5-16-23 LOC npcc.08535 (cropped) (cropped).jpg | caption = Alisa Mellon in 1923 |birth_name=Ailsa Mellon | birth_date = {{Birth date|1901|06|28|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]], U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|1969|08|25|1901|06|28|df=yes}} | death_place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | residence = [[960 Fifth Avenue]] | education = [[Miss Porter's School]] | known_for = Founder of the [[Avalon Foundation]] | parents = [[Andrew W. Mellon]]
Nora McMullen | spouse = {{marriage|[[David K. E. Bruce]]
|1926|1945|reason=div}} | children = Audrey Sheila Bruce }} '''Ailsa Mellon Bruce''' (June 28, 1901 – August 25, 1969) was a prominent American socialite and philanthropist who established the [[Avalon Foundation]]. ==Early life== Ailsa was born in [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania|Pittsburgh]], Pennsylvania, on June 28, 1901. She was the daughter of the banker and diplomat [[Andrew W. Mellon]] and Nora Mary ([[née]] McMullen) Mellon (1879–1937). Her parents divorced in 1912 and from 1921 to 1932, Ailsa served as her father's official hostess during his tenure as [[United States Secretary of the Treasury]], and again when he was [[United States Ambassador to the United Kingdom|U.S. Ambassador to the United Kingdom]] in 1932–1933. Her only sibling was brother [[Paul Mellon]] (1907–1999), who was also a philanthropist and was known as a prominent owner/breeder of [[thoroughbred racehorses]].{{cite news|last1=Russell|first1=John|title=Paul Mellon, Patrician Champion Of Art and National Gallery, Dies|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/02/03/books/paul-mellon-patrician-champion-of-art-and-national-gallery-dies.html|accessdate=16 April 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=3 February 1999}} Ailsa attended [[Miss Porter's School]] in [[Farmington, Connecticut]] and spent her summers as a teenager in Europe. ==Philanthropy and legacy== Bruce established the [[Avalon Foundation]] in 1940, which made [[Grant (money)|grants]] to colleges and [[universities]], [[medical school]]s and [[hospital]]s, [[youth program]]s and [[community services]], [[Church body|churches]], [[environmentalist|environmental projects]], and an array of cultural and [[fine arts|arts organization]]s. In 1947, the Avalon Foundation was instrumental in the establishment of the [[Hampton National Historic Site]] in [[Maryland]].{{cite news|last1=Brown|first1=Nona B.|title=18th-Century Indulgence Becomes a 20th-Century Showplace|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1969/10/19/archives/18thcentury-indulgence-becomes-a-20thcentury-showplace.html|accessdate=16 April 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=19 October 1969}} In 1957, when ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'' prepared its first list of the [[Wealthiest Americans (1957)|wealthiest Americans]], it estimated that Ailsa Mellon Bruce, her brother, [[Paul Mellon|Paul]], and her cousins, [[Sarah Mellon]] and [[Richard King Mellon]], were all among the richest eight people in the United States, with fortunes of between 400 and 700 million dollars each. In 1968, Ailsa and Paul donated $20 million to build an annex to the [[National Gallery of Art]] in [[Washington, D.C.]]{{cite news|last1=Robertson|first1=Nan|title=National Gallery Honors a Patron|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1969/09/01/archives/national-gallery-honors-a-patron.html|accessdate=16 April 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=1 September 1969}} At her death in 1969, Ailsa Bruce bequeathed 153 [[paintings]], primarily by 19th-century [[French Artists|French artists]], to the [[National Gallery of Art]], as well as establishing a fund for future acquisitions. Among the many works acquired by the Gallery through the Ailsa Mellon Bruce Fund was the portrait of ''[https://www.nga.gov/collection/art-object-page.50724.html Ginevra de' Benci]'', the only painting by [[Leonardo da Vinci]] in the United States.{{Cite web|url=https://www.nga.gov/features/slideshows/founding-benefactors-of-the-national-gallery-of-art.html|title=Founding Benefactors of the National Gallery of Art|website=www.nga.gov|access-date=2018-03-16}} In 1969, the assets of [[Paul Mellon]]’s Old Dominion Foundation were merged into his sister's Avalon Foundation, which was renamed the [[Andrew W. Mellon Foundation]] in honor of their father.{{Cite web|url=https://mellon.org/about/history/founders/|title=Founders {{!}} The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation|website=mellon.org|language=en|access-date=2018-03-16}}{{cite news|title=Foundations Join to Become Mellon|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1969/06/30/archives/foundations-join-to-become-mellon.html|accessdate=16 April 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=30 June 1969}} ==Personal life== [[File:Ailsa Mellon Bruce.jpg|thumb|left|Portrait by [[Philip de László]], 1926]] She dated [[Fürst von Bismarck|Prince]] [[Otto Christian Archibald von Bismarck|Otto Bismarck]], the grandson of [[Otto von Bismarck]], the "Iron Chancellor", and was close to marrying him, but decided to marry David Bruce, an American, instead. On May 23, 1926, she was married to [[David K. E. Bruce|David Kirkpatrick Este Bruce]] (1898–1977), a scion of a prominent [[Virginia]] family including his father [[William Cabell Bruce]], a [[U.S. Senator]] from Maryland, and brother [[James Cabell Bruce]], the [[U.S. Ambassador to Argentina]].{{cite news|title=REPORT AILSA MELLON TO WED DAVID BRUCE; Secretary's Daughter Is Said to Be Engaged to Son of Maryland Senator.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1926/05/03/archives/report-ailsa-mellon-to-wed-david-bruce-secretarys-daughter-is-said.html|accessdate=16 April 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=3 May 1926}} Their engagement, marriage (which was attended by [[Calvin Coolidge|President]] and [[Grace Coolidge|Mrs. Coolidge]]) and honeymoon were followed closely by the news media.{{cite news|title=MISS MELLON TO WED, FATHER ANNOUNCES; Secretary of Treasury's Daughter to Be Bride of D.K.E. Bruce, Senator's Son.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1926/05/04/archives/miss-mellon-to-wed-father-announces-secretary-of-treasurys-daughter.html|accessdate=16 April 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=4 May 1926}}{{cite news|title=PRESIDENT TO ATTEND MELLON BRIDAL TODAY 8,000 Invited to Wedding Reception of Secretary's Daughter and David Bruce.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1926/05/29/archives/president-to-attend-mellon-bridal-today-8000-invit-o-w-ing-recep.html|accessdate=16 April 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=29 May 1926}}{{cite news|title=MELLON'S DAUGHTER SAILS AS A BRIDE; The Bruces Depart for Rome, Where He Will Take Up Duties as Vice Consul.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1926/06/03/archives/mellons-daughter-sails-as-a-bride-the-bruces-depart-for-rome-where.html|accessdate=16 April 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=3 June 1926}}{{cite news|title=BRUCES ARRIVE IN ENGLAND.; Senator's Son and Bride Leave for Paris on Way to Live in Rome.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1926/06/11/archives/bruces-arrive-in-england-senators-son-and-bride-leave-for-paris-on.html|accessdate=16 April 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=11 June 1926}} In 1933, after seven years of marriage, Ailsa gave birth to her only child;Cannadine, David. ''Mellon: An American Life,'' Vintage Books, 2008. * Audrey Sheila Bruce (1934–1967), who married Stephen Richard Currier (1930–1967),{{cite news|title=STEPHEN CURRIERS MISSING ON FLIGHT; Caribbean Search Is On for New York Philanthropists Stephen Curriers Missing on a Flight|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1967/01/19/archives/stephen-curriers-missing-on-flight-caribbean-search-is-on-for-new.html|accessdate=16 April 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 19, 1967}} who went missing during a flight in the [[Caribbean]] in January 1967 and were never recovered.{{cite news|title=800 ATTEND RITES FOR THE CURRIERS; 2 Philanthropists Lost on Flight Eulogized Here|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1967/02/16/archives/800-attend-rites-for-the-curriers-2-philanthropists-lost-on-flight.html|accessdate=16 April 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=16 February 1967}} They were the founders of the Taconic Foundation, a charitable giving organization, which was instrumental in the formation of the [[Council for United Civil Rights Leadership]].{{cite news|title=CURRIER FUND DUE TO PICK NEW HEAD; Taconic Unit Will Carry On With $20-Million Bequest|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1967/02/26/archives/currier-fund-due-to-pick-new-head-taconic-unit-will-carry-on-with.html|accessdate=16 April 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=26 February 1967}} She obtained a divorce from her husband in [[Palm Beach, Florida]] in April 1945 on the grounds of "desertion and mental cruelty", receiving sole custody of their 11 year old daughter.{{cite news|title=AILSA BRUCE GETS DECREE; Daughter of Andrew Mellon Wins a Florida Divorce|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1945/04/21/archives/ailsa-bruce-gets-decree-daughter-of-andrew-mellon-wins-a-florida.html|accessdate=16 April 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=21 April 1945}} Following their divorce, her ex-husband would later become the [[United States Ambassador to the United Kingdom]] from 1961 to 1969, the same position her father held.{{cite news |first= Marylynne|last= Pitz|authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Ailsa Mellon Bruce's artworks part of Carnegie collection |url=http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/09319/1013040-437.stm#ixzz0Z8KF5ZPx |quote=In 1926, the beautiful, reserved and stubborn young woman married David K. E. Bruce, a talented lawyer and the son of Maryland Sen. William C. Bruce. For wedding presents, A. W. Mellon gave his daughter a pearl necklace valued at $100,000 and a 200-acre estate in Syosset, Long Island. |work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] |date=November 15, 2009 |accessdate=2009-12-08 }} She died on August 25, 1969 at [[Roosevelt Hospital]] in New York City.{{cite news|title=Died - BRUCE--Ailsa Mellon|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1969/08/27/archives/obituary-1-no-title.html|accessdate=16 April 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=27 August 1969}} She had homes at [[960 Fifth Avenue]] and a 121 acre estate in [[Syosset, New York]] on [[Long Island]]. Her obituary in ''[[The New York Times]]'' called her the "Richest Woman in U.S."{{cite news|title=Mrs. Ailsa Mellon Bruce Dead;. Called Richest Woman in U. S|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1969/08/26/archives/mrs-ailsa-mellon-bruce-dead-called-richest-woman-in-u-s.html|accessdate=16 April 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=26 August 1969}} ===Descendants=== When Audrey and her husband, Stephen Currier, died in a presumed plane crash in 1967, leaving three young children – Andrea Currier,{{cite news|last1=Bruske|first1=Ed|title=The Brad Baker Murder: ‘As the World Turns’ in Fauquier County|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/the-brad-baker-murder-as-the-world-turns-in-fauquier-county/2013/01/15/6ec59630-5f3f-11e2-a389-ee565c81c565_story.html|accessdate=16 April 2018|work=[[Washington Post]]|date=12 January 1981}} Lavinia Currier,{{cite news|last1=Grove|first1=Lloyd|title=Child of Fortune, Take 2|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/style/features/currier.htm|accessdate=16 April 2018|work=[[Washington Post]]|date=July 8, 1998}} and Michael Stephen Currier (1961–1998),{{cite news|last1=Pace|first1=Eric|title=Michael Currier, 37, Philanthropic Rancher Who Helped Tibetans|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/22/us/michael-currier-37-philanthropic-rancher-who-helped-tibetans.html|accessdate=16 April 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=22 September 1998}} she decided to [[bequeath]] her collection of 18th-century English furniture and [[Ceramics (art)|ceramics]] to the [[Carnegie Museum of Art|Carnegie Institute]] of [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]].{{cite news|title=Mrs. Ailsa Mellon Bruce Left Bulk of Her Estate to Charity|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1969/09/04/archives/mrs-ailsa-mellon-bruce-left-bulk-of-her-estate-to-charity.html|accessdate=16 April 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=4 September 1969}} == Gallery == File:Saint George and the Dragon Rogier.jpg|[[Rogier van der Weyden]], Saint George and the Dragon, c. 1432-1435 (NGA 1966.1.1) File:Leonardo da Vinci - Ginevra de' Benci - Google Art Project.jpg|[[Leonardo da Vinci]], Ginevra de' Benci, c. 1474-1478 (NGA 1967.6.1) File:Sir Peter Paul Rubens - Daniel in the Lions' Den - Google Art Project.jpg|[[Peter Paul Rubens]], Daniel in the Lions' Den, c. 1614-1616 (NGA 1965.13.1) File:Georges de La Tour - The Repentant Magdalen - Google Art Project.jpg|[[Georges de La Tour]], The Repentant Magdalen, c. 1635-1640 (NGA 1974.52.1) File:John Adams - by Gilbert Stuart - c 1821 - Natl Portrait Gallery Washington DC.jpg|[[Gilbert Stuart]], [[John Adams]], c. 1821 (NGA 1979.4.1) File:Thomas Cole - The Voyage of Life Childhood, 1842 (National Gallery of Art).jpg|[[Thomas Cole]], The Voyage of Life: Childhood, 1842 (NGA 1971.16.1) ==See also== [[Wealthiest Americans (1957)]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category|Ailsa Mellon Bruce}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20050906184236/http://www.mellon.org/Founders/Content-Ailsa.htm The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080925084443/http://www.nga.gov/cgi-bin/pbio?1062 The National Gallery of Art] *{{findagrave|15711163}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bruce Mellon, Ailsa}} [[Category:American art collectors]] [[Category:Women art collectors]] [[Category:Mellon family]] [[Category:1901 births]] [[Category:1969 deaths]] [[Category:People from Pittsburgh]] [[Category:American people of Scotch-Irish descent]] [[Category:People from Suffolk County, New York]]
